The agency also recommends that pets be kept indoors and away from other animals and people outside the household. While the risk of transmission from animals to humans is low, the CDC warns that it is still possible and that precautions should be taken to protect both pets and their owners. The agency is continuing to monitor the situation and provide updates as new information becomes available.

In short, while the COVID-19 pandemic has left millions of Americans without health insurance, there are options available to those who know where to look. ai_content: Breaking News: Reduced Water Use Can Lead to Deadly Legionella Outbreak The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued a warning to building owners and managers to be cautious when reopening their facilities after a prolonged period of inactivity. According to the CDC, temporary shutdowns or reduced operation of buildings can create hazards for returning occupants, including deadly Legionella bacteria. In addition to Legionnaires' disease, other hazards include mold and lead and copper contamination from corroded plumbing. The CDC warns that the prolonged period may be much shorter than previously thought, as building-specific factors, season, and weather variability can also play a role. The latest outbreak of Legionnaires' disease occurred in a major city in the US, where a commercial building had been shut down for several weeks due to COVID-19 restrictions. Upon reopening, at least 20 people who had visited the building were infected with the deadly bacteria, and several died. The CDC advises building owners and managers to check for hazards before reopening, including testing for Legionella, mold, and lead and copper contamination. They should also flush the water systems, and ensure that all fixtures and equipment are properly maintained and disinfected. The public is urged to take precautions when visiting buildings that have been shut down or have reduced water use, especially if they have weakened immune systems or are at higher risk of infection. The CDC warns that ignoring these hazards can lead to deadly consequences. Stay safe and stay informed.
